description.plain: Deep Purple is one of the defining Hard Rock bands of the 70’s, and is co-credited with such bands as Black Sabbath and Led Zeppelin of creating the genre of Heavy Metal. They are best known for their song “Smoke on the Water”, as well as utilizing heavily distorted organ playing to mold their own unique heavy sound.

body.plain: Deep Purple is one of the defining Hard Rock bands of the 70’s, and is co-credited with such bands as Black Sabbath and Led Zeppelin of creating the genre of Heavy Metal. They are best known for their song “Smoke on the Water”, as well as utilizing heavily distorted organ playing to mold their own unique heavy sound.

songs.full_title: Smoke on the Water by Deep Purple
songs.title: Smoke on the Water

description.plain:
One of the most recognizable guitar riffs in rock'n'roll history. “Smoke on the Water” tells the true story of a fire igniting during a 1971 Frank Zappa concert in Montreux, Switzerland, where the band had come to record their next album, Machine Head.



The song made it to number four, their first top ten since “Hush” in 1968. It was also their first single to receive certification, being granted a gold record by the RIAA.

82 ContributorsSmoke on the Water Lyrics

We all came out to Montreux
On the Lake Geneva shoreline
To make records with a mobile
We didn't have much time
But Frank Zappa and the Mothers
Were at the best place around
But some stupid with a flare gun
Burned the place to the ground

Smoke on the water
And fire in the sky
Smoke on the water

They burned down the gambling house
It died with an awful sound
Funky Claude was running in and out
Pulling kids out the ground
When it all was over
We had to find another place
But Swiss time was running out
It seemed that we would lose the race
You might also like
Smoke on the water
And fire in the sky
Smoke on the water

We ended up at the Grand Hotel
It was empty, cold and bare
But with the Rolling-truck-Stones-thing just outside
Making our music there
With a few red lights, a few old beds
We made a place to sweat
No matter what, we get out of this
I know, I know we'll never forget

Smoke on the water
And fire in the sky
Smoke on the water
23Embed

songs.full_title: Child in Time by Deep Purple
songs.title: Child in Time

description.plain:
Written by Ritchie Blackmore, Ian Gillan, Roger Glover, Jon Lord and Ian Paice from Deep Purple’s 1970 album Deep Purple In Rock

“Child In Time” is an anti-Vietnam War protest song considered the band’s epic achievement as well as one of the greatest progressive rock pieces of all time.

Each member’s musical strengths created a composition that so powerfully captured the moods and chaos of the times highlighted by Jon Lord’s haunting organ, Ritchie Blackmore’s bluesy machine gun-like guitar solos and Ian Gillan’s vocal in what is perhaps the finest performance in the history of the heavy metal/hard rock genre.

Gillan has admitted “Child In Time” is based on  American band It’s A Beautiful Day’s 1969 psychedelic rock piece Bombay Calling. Though faster paced and violin driven, Deep Purple borrowed a substantial part of the arrangement as the basis for Lord and Blackmore’s instrumental riffs and solos. In 1970 It’s A Beautiful Day lifted Deep Purple’s “Wring That Neck” and morphed it into “Don And Dewey” from their second album Marrying Maiden.

Deep Purple in Rock marked a return to their rock roots after flirting with classical music influences in some of their previous work.



A very apt album cover, Deep Purple In Rock is considered a cornerstone with Black Sabbath’s first two albums in 1970, as the foundation of what became heavy metal (here).

songs.full_title: Highway Star by Deep Purple
songs.title: Highway Star

description.plain:
“Highway Star” is a song by the English rock band Deep Purple. It is the opening track on their 1972 album Machine Head and is the fastest song in tempo on the album. It was released as the lead single and, despite not charting, it is still considered one of their most popular songs.

This song was born on a tour bus going to Portsmouth in 1971 when a reporter asked the band how they wrote songs. To demonstrate, guitarist Ritchie Blackmore grabbed an acoustic guitar and began playing a riff consisting of a single “G” repeated over and over, while vocalist Ian Gillan improvised lyrics over the top. The song was refined and was performed that same night.

songs.full_title: Hush by Deep Purple
songs.title: Hush

description.plain:
Off their hit album “Shades of Deep Purple”, the song itself made it to number four. Originally recorded by Billy Joe Royal in 1967, it was covered by Deep Purple the following year.

The song was their first single and their only top ten hit until Smoke on the Water in 1973.

songs.full_title: Burn by Deep Purple
songs.title: Burn

description.plain:
The opening title track to Deep Purple’s 1974 album of the same name, and one of the singles for the album. “Burn” was the first song recorded by the band’s Mark III lineup, which featured Ritchie Blackmore on guitar, Jon Lord on keyboards, Ian Paice on drums, David Coverdale on lead vocals, and Glenn Hughes on bass and vocals. It’s considered one of the best album openers for any Deep Purple album alongside Highway Star. It was and still is never performed live when the previous singer Ian Gillan came back to the band in 1984, and again in 1992.

Later, in 2015, David Coverdale (with his newer band Whitesnake) recorded a cover of this song for their album of Deep Purple covers called The Purple Album. He also frequently performed covers of this song (and others from his time with them) live with Whitesnake over the years. Ritchie Blackmore’s other band Rainbow has also performed the song live on various concerts. Glenn Hughes re-recorded it as a US and Japan bonus song on his 1994 solo album From Now On….

songs.full_title: When a Blind Man Cries by Deep Purple
songs.title: When a Blind Man Cries

description.plain:
“When a Blind Man Cries” is a song by the British rock band Deep Purple. It was released in March 1972 and was recorded in December 1971. The songwriters are Ritchie Blackmore, Ian Gillan, Roger Glover, Jon Lord and Ian Paice. Ian Gillan said of this song:

“It’s just an example, for example, if you think of the phrase ‘if a blind man cries’ then it’s pretty sad, those who are disadvantaged tend to be less complaining than those who are able-bodied”.

The man this song refers to, is possibly not literally blind, but metaphorically, since he can no longer see the things in life that matter most. He can no longer see happiness or love (“And my world is pale”). This song offers powerful images that depict sadness and a feeling of hopelessness and solitude.

songs.full_title: Strange Kind of Woman by Deep Purple
songs.title: Strange Kind of Woman

description.plain:
The song is about about a woman who looked pretty normal for a woman, but drove guys wild anyway.

When played live, this song would often involve an extended outro after the majority of the song had been played, with most of the band dropping out except for Ian Paice’s drums, allowing guitarist Ritchie Blackmore and vocalist Ian Gillan to have an extended guitar/vocal duel, with Blackmore playing licks and Gillan mimicking them with his voice.

songs.full_title: Knocking at Your Back Door by Deep Purple
songs.title: Knocking at Your Back Door

description.plain:
“Knocking at Your Back Door” is a song by the British hard rock band Deep Purple, the first track of the album “Perfect Strangers”, which was released in September 1984. Song was written by Ritchie Blackmore, Ian Gillan and Roger Glover. The track was widely broadcast by the media of that time.

Ian Gillan said about this song: “There’s this guy named Redbeard, from a radio station down in Texas. He phoned me up after it had been played on every radio station in America and said, ‘Is this what I think it’s about?’ And I said, ‘Yeah.’ And he said, ‘It’s amazing, every radio station in America is playing a song written about anal sex and they don’t even realize what’s going on.’ And I was like, well it’s not in-your-face anal sex, it’s just a joke. It just came about with the lyrics. It’s no big deal. But it’s a humorous thing and not meant to be offensive. And I think it was just an afterthought. It certainly wasn’t what inspired the song”.[1]

The song, released on 7" vinyl and CD with “Perfect Strangers” on the second side, in October 1984.[2] In Canada, the second side of the singles was the instrumental “Son of Alerik”,[3] while in Japan,[4] Spain[5] and the United States[6] released a version with “Wasted Sunsets”. “Knocking at Your Back Door” was a permanent part of the band’s live set until 1994 and sporadically since then. Live albums that include the track are: Nobody’s Perfect (1988), In the Absence of Pink (1991), Come Hell or High Water (DVD, 1994), Live in Europe 1993 (2007), Live at Montreux 2011 (2011)

songs.full_title: Space Truckin' by Deep Purple
songs.title: Space Truckin’

description.plain:
“Space Truckin'” is the final song on most releases of Machine Head. The concept of the song came about when Ritchie Blackmore proposed the idea of combining concepts of space travel with late 1960’s comic Keep On Truckin'.

When performed live, this song would often turn into very extended jams, with the original recording of the song on the album only being four and a half minutes in length, these jams would often reach upwards of 15 minutes, with the version recorded for Made in Japan being nearly 20 minutes long.

Perhaps the most notable live performance of “Space Truckin'” came from Deep Purple’s performance at the 1974 California Jam. Due to miscommunication with concert organizers, guitarist Ritchie Blackmore had become extremely upset. During the extended jam, Blackmore destroyed multiple guitars, smashed a camera with a guitar, and had his guitar amp doused in gasoline and lit on fire, causing it to explode.

songs.full_title: Black Night by Deep Purple
songs.title: Black Night

description.plain:
“Black Night” was the first single off of Deep Purple’s fourth studio album Deep Purple in Rock.

The track became Deep Purple’s highest-charting song in the UK; the main riff features the pentatonic blues scale. Another highlight of the song includes Ritchie Blackmore blazing guitar solo filled with pick slides and whammy bar use.

Other highlights of the song include Jon Lord’s fiery organ playing and Ian Gillan’s powerful vocals. The song is written in the key of A major and is played in 4/4 time.

songs.full_title: Lazy by Deep Purple
songs.title: Lazy

description.plain:
“Lazy” is the sixth track off of Deep Purple’s sixth studio album Machine Head.

The song begins with Jon Lord’s shrieking overdriven Hammond organ, playing in a blues-based scale, particularly, the C Jam Blues. After the first minute, appears the main riff by Ritchie Blackmore. Then, the song breaks into a free-form jam, with Ritchie Blackmore soloing over parts of a theme from Hugo Alfvén’s “Swedish Rhapsody #1”, but in a blues based style.

After that, follows Jon Lord’s solo, played as well in the blues-based style. The vocals appear after four minutes of jamming. Other highlights of the song is the harmonica played by Ian Gillan, and the final guitar solo played by Ritchie Blackmore, soloing fast arpeggios in A minor.

songs.full_title: All I Got Is You by Deep Purple
songs.title: All I Got Is You

description.plain:
All I Got Is You is the second single from Deep Purple’s album inFinite.

The song features the purest Deep Purple classic sound while staying well away from the temptation to be nostalgic: in fact, the band add some prog-like solutions which were featured on their previous album, Now What?!.

An official music video had been released for this song: it includes images from the 97 minute movie documentary From Here To inFinite and gives an in-depth insight into the band’s songwriting and recording process, for the first time allowing cameras in the studio.

songs.full_title: Stormbringer by Deep Purple
songs.title: Stormbringer

description.plain:
Stormbringer’s title comes from Michael Moorkock’s mythology it being a legendary sword and the title of one of his books of the Elric series.  Although David Coverdale has denied he knew of that fact.



According to Glenn Hughes, the slurred gibberish that is spoken by Coverdale at the beginning of the title track just prior to the first verse is the same backwards dialogue that Linda Blair’s character utters in the film The Exorcist, when she is questioned by the priest.

songs.full_title: Pictures of Home by Deep Purple
songs.title: Pictures of Home

description.plain:
“Pictures of Home” is the third track off of Deep Purple’s sixth studio album, Machine Head.

This song, written in the key of C minor, features instrumental solos from every band member. Ritchie Blackmore plays two guitar solos full of long bends and melodic arpeggiated lines. An organ solo from Jon Lord is also featured with the use of a piano slide.

The song tells the tale a stranded mountain climber who is longing for home. Other highlights on this song is the short, powerful bass solo from Roger Glover, and Ian Paice’s blistering drums.

songs.full_title: Maybe I'm a Leo by Deep Purple
songs.title: Maybe I’m a Leo

description.plain:
Maybe I’m a Leo is the second track off of Deep Purple’s sixth studio album, Machine Head.

The track, written in the key of C minor, features and heavy blues-based riff written by bassist Roger Glover, and two bluesy guitar solos played by Ritchie Blackmore, that featured long bends and arpeggiated notes.

The song tells of a man who’s grieving over his kidnapped lover. Other highlights of this song include Ian Paice’s blistering drumming and Jon Lord’s timeless organ solo.

songs.full_title: Fireball by Deep Purple
songs.title: Fireball

description.plain:
“Fireball” is the opening track off of Deep Purple’s fifth studio album, Fireball.

This track, written in the key of B minor, begins with the sound of an air conditioner being turned on. This is one of the few tracks in Deep Purple’s catalogue to not feature a guitar solo from Ritchie Blackmore.

The song tells of a mysterious feminine entity that a man falls in love with. Other highlights of this song include the short, distorted bass solo from Roger Glover, Ian Paice’s fast drumming and Jon Lord’s timeless organ work.

songs.full_title: Mistreated by Deep Purple
songs.title: Mistreated

description.plain:
“Mistreated” is the seventh track off of Deep Purple’s eighth studio album, Burn.

The song, written in the key of F sharp minor, features heavy blues-based influences in the guitar main riff and lyrics, that detail a man’s self-abuse over the mistreatment he faced with his lover.

Highlights of this song include several briskly played solo’s from Ritchie Blackmore, the high pitched and pure vocals of David Coverdale and Ian Paice’s prevalent drumming. A notorious performance of this song was at the California Jam in 1974.
